dsDescriptionValue.value:
Active Timeline for data production and upload is located at:
https://github.com/CoryAndrewHofstad/Electroacoustic-Propulsion/projects/1

The wave assisted propulsion system project develops and studies novel electronic propulsion methods which use acoustic catalysts. The project was started within North Seattle College’s Undergraduate Research 294 Program in Fall of 2017, by aerospace engineering student Cory Andrew Hofstad. Plasma Vortex Theory was developed during a night spent watching back-to-back NASA aerospace videos on YouTube looking for a project idea for UGR 294. From the observation of rotational formations created in Lycopodium in the video documentary “Cymatic Soundscapes” by Hans Jenny, a theory was derived by combining Newtons’ first law of motion with Lorentz’s force law and Coulomb’s force law. The theory has two components:

  1. Through Lorentz’s force and the right-hand rule, an electroacoustic method could be used to increase an ionized particle’s velocity parallel to an electromagnetic field.
  2. A rotating ion cloud will have a higher final velocity then an ion cloud at rest when electromagnetic fields of equal force are applied.

publicationCitation.value: Jahn, R. G., & Choueiri, E. Y. (2003). Electric Propulsion. Encyclopedia of Physical Science and Technology, 125-141.
Lun, J., & Law, C. (2015). Influence of Cathode Shape on Vacuum Arc Thruster Performance and Operation. IEEE Transactions On Plasma Science, 43(1), 198-208.
Poizin, K. A., & Reneau, J. P. (2009). Effect of Conductive Walls on the Performance of a Pulsed Inductive Thruster. IEEE Transactions On Plasma Science, 37(2), 359-364.

Uchigashima, A., Baba, T., Ichihara, D., Iwakawa, A., Sasoh, A., Yamazaki, T., & ... Iwasaki, T. (2016). Anode Geometry Effects on Ion Beam Energy Performance in Helicon Electrostatic Thruster. IEEE Transactions On Plasma Science, 44(3), 306-313.

Ding, Y., Boyang, J., Sun, H., Wei, L., Peng, W., Li, P., & Yu, D. (2018). Effect of matching between the magnetic field and channel length on the performance of low sputtering Hall thrusters. Advances In Space Research, 61(3), 837-843.

Holak, K., Wonho, C., Youbong, L., Seunghun, L., & Sanghoo, P. (2017). Magnetic field configurations on thruster performance in accordance with ion beam characteristics in cylindrical Hall thruster plasmas. Applied Physics Letters, 110(11), 1-5.
Peng, H., Hui, L., Yuanyuan, G., & Daren, Y. (2016). Effects of magnetic field strength in the discharge channel on the performance of a multi-cusped field thruster. AIP
Jenny, H. (2001). Cymatics: A Study of Wave Phenomena & Vibration (Vol. I & II).
Jenny, H. (Director). (2006). Cymatics Soundscapes: And Bringing Matter To Life With Sound.

fields.value: Sources use new application methods for known physical principals and are all reputable aerospace engineers.

files.description:
The wave assisted propulsion system project develops and studies novel electronic propulsion methods which use acoustic catalysts. The project was started within North Seattle College’s Undergraduate Research 294 Program in Fall of 2017, by aerospace engineering student Cory Andrew Hofstad. Plasma Vortex Theory was developed during a night spent watching back-to-back NASA aerospace videos on YouTube looking for a project idea for UGR 294. From the observation of rotational formations created in Lycopodium in the video documentary “Cymatic Soundscapes” by Hans Jenny, a theory was derived by combining Newtons’ first law of motion with Lorentz’s force law and Coulomb’s force law. The theory has two components:
 
1. Through Lorentz’s force and the right-hand rule, an electroacoustic method could be used to increase an ionized particle’s velocity parallel to an electromagnetic field.
2. A rotating ion cloud will have a higher final velocity then an ion cloud at rest when electromagnetic fields of equal force are applied.

Electric propulsion (EP) systems depend on a hybrid combination of electrical energy and chemical fuel to create thrust. These systems are relied on by space flight missions for their ability to extend the life of a finite chemical fuel supply. During prolonged orbits and extended travel timelines, EP drives and thrusters are able to increase the distance that an applied spacecraft is able to travel. Future spaceflight missions need increasingly efficient propulsion systems for long-term orbital missions and interplanetary or interstellar transit missions. In electric propulsion applications, thruster performance is generally measured in terms of the efficiency at which chemical fuel is spent to achieve a measured thrust force. Published methods for increasing thruster performance include manipulation of cathode shape, wall materials, anode geometry, channel length, magnetic field strength, and column configuration.

Electroacoustic propulsion is a method of accelerating a chemical propellant using waves of sound inside a thruster column or pre-exhaust chamber. This process of increasing kinetic energy is designed to operate as a catalyst for creating exhaust velocities in cooperation with traditional electric propulsion methods.
files.label: SPRING2018INDEPENDENTSTUDY.docx

The wave assisted propulsion system project develops and studies novel electronic propulsion methods which use acoustic catalysts. The project was started within North Seattle College’s Undergraduate Research 294 Program in Fall of 2017, by aerospace engineering student Cory Andrew Hofstad. From the observation of rotational formations created in Lycopodium in the video documentary “Cymatic Soundscapes” by Hans Jenny, a theory was derived by combining Newtons’ first law of motion with Lorentz’s force law and Coulomb’s force law. The theory has two components:
 
1. Through Lorentz’s force and the right-hand rule, an electroacoustic method could be used to increase an ionized particle’s velocity parallel to an electromagnetic field.
2. A rotating ion cloud will have a higher final velocity then an ion cloud at rest when electromagnetic fields of equal force are applied.

Electric propulsion (EP) systems depend on a hybrid combination of electrical energy and chemical fuel to create thrust. These systems are relied on by space flight missions for their ability to extend the life of a finite chemical fuel supply. During prolonged orbits and extended travel timelines, EP drives and thrusters are able to increase the distance that an applied spacecraft is able to travel. Future spaceflight missions need increasingly efficient propulsion systems for long-term orbital missions and interplanetary or interstellar transit missions. In electric propulsion applications, thruster performance is generally measured in terms of the efficiency at which chemical fuel is spent to achieve a measured thrust force. Published methods for increasing thruster performance include manipulation of cathode shape, wall materials, anode geometry, channel length, magnetic field strength, and column configuration.

Electroacoustic propulsion is a method of accelerating a chemical propellant using waves of sound inside a thruster column or pre-exhaust chamber. This process of increasing kinetic energy is designed to operate as a catalyst for creating exhaust velocities in cooperation with traditional electric propulsion methods.
